communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

All documents (including emails, texts, and any other communications) concerning the scheduling of pedestrian and bicycle access to Riverbend Park in Cambridge in 2023, including, but not limited to, documents and communications concerning whether or not to close Memorial Drive/Riverbend Park to vehicular traffic on Saturdays.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jacob Walker

title: Disciplinary Files and Logs of Mayor Eric Adams During his Tenure with the Department (1984-2006)

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to request access to specific records related to the disciplinary files and logs of now Mayor Eric Adams of New York City during his time with the New York City Police Department. Mayor Adams served with the department from 1984 to 2006. I am requesting the following records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL):

All records related to disciplinary actions taken against Eric Adams during his time with the New York City Police Department, including disciplinary files and logs.

Any and all records related to changes, edits, and copies of the responsive documents identified in item 1 above.

A list of all individuals who had access to the records identified in items 1 and 2 above during Eric Adams' tenure with the New York City Police Department.

As a member of the public, I have a right to access these records to gain a better understanding of the professional conduct and performance of now Mayor Eric Adams during his time with the New York City Police Department.

Please be advised that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint. The failure to comply with FOIL is a serious matter and can result in both criminal and civil penalties. Therefore, I strongly urge you to comply with this request in a timely and complete manner.

Last, I would like to bring to your attention the case law supporting my request:

New York City Administrative Code Section 14-151 (a) requires the New York Police Department to maintain records of all complaints and allegations of police misconduct, including records of investigations and findings.

New York State Committee on Open Government, Advisory Opinion #2016-4 (2016) states that police body-worn camera footage is presumptively available under FOIL.

Matter of Fappiano v. New York City Police Department, 95 A.D.3d 981 (2d Dep't 2012) held that "FOIL represents a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed."

New York Times Co. v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 756 F.3d 100, 117 (2d Cir. 2014) (holding that "the public has a vital interest in information regarding the operations of its government" and that the FOIA "embodies the basic principle that an informed citizenry is essential to democracy").

Matter of DaimlerChrysler Corp. v. Spitzer, 7 N.Y.3d 653, 663 (2006) (stating that "FOIL, like FOIA, reflects a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed").

Please note that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Good Citizen

title: Police Records: Regarding Incident  Officer Daniel Calixte Badge #863 and Incident Case Number 202201119

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Police Records: Regarding Incident  Officer Daniel Calixte Badge #863 and Incident Case Number 202201119
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I am writing to request access to specific records related to an incident involving Officer Daniel Calixte Badge #863 from the 63rd Precinct with case number 202201119, which occurred on December 15, 2021. 

I am requesting the following records under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA):

Body-worn camera footage from Officer Daniel Calixte Badge #863 during the incident with Case number 202201119 on December 15, 2021.

911 audio recordings and dashcam footage or messages system on agency computer system related to the incident with Case number 202201119 on December 15, 2021.

Body-worn camera footage from all other officers involved in the incident with Case number 202201119 on December 15, 2021.

I urge you to carefully read and comply with this request, as I believe that the requested records are of significant public interest and concern. The incident involving Officer Daniel Calixte Badge #863 resulted in a public outcry and raised questions about police conduct and use of force. As a member of the public, I have a right to access these records to gain a better understanding of the incident and to hold law enforcement accountable.

Please be advised that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint. The failure to comply with FOIL is a serious matter and can result in both criminal and civil penalties. Therefore, I strongly urge you to comply with this request in a timely and complete manner.

Last, I would like to bring to your attention the case law supporting my request:

New York City Administrative Code Section 14-151 (a) requires the New York Police Department to maintain records of all complaints and allegations of police misconduct, including records of investigations and findings.

New York State Committee on Open Government, Advisory Opinion #2016-4 (2016) states that police body-worn camera footage is presumptively available under FOIL.

Matter of Fappiano v. New York City Police Department, 95 A.D.3d 981 (2d Dep't 2012) held that "FOIL represents a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed."

New York Times Co. v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 756 F.3d 100, 117 (2d Cir. 2014) (holding that "the public has a vital interest in information regarding the operations of its government" and that the FOIA "embodies the basic principle that an informed citizenry is essential to democracy").

Matter of DaimlerChrysler Corp. v. Spitzer, 7 N.Y.3d 653, 663 (2006) (stating that "FOIL, like FOIA, reflects a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed").

Please note that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Good Citizen

title: Police Records: Regarding Incident Involving Officers Garcia, Burke, and Leone (Case #201904461)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Police Records: Regarding Incident Involving Officers Garcia, Burke, and Leone (Case #201904461)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

I  am writing to request access to specific records related to an incident involving Officers Brian C. Garcia Badge #30586, Timothy J. Burke Badge #3879, and Patrick L. Leone Badge #20045, with case number 201904461, which occurred on January 24, 2019.

 I am requesting the following records under the Freedom of Information Law (FOIL):

Complaint records filed against Officers Brian C. Garcia, Timothy J. Burke, and Patrick L. Leone related to case number 201904461.

All records and documents related to the investigation of the incident with case number 201904461, including any written reports, witness statements, and evidence collected.

Body-worn camera footage from Officers Brian C. Garcia, Timothy J. Burke, and Patrick L. Leone during the incident with case number 201904461 on January 24, 2019.

I urge you to carefully read and comply with this request, as I believe that the requested records are of significant public interest and concern. The incident involving Officers Brian C. Garcia, Timothy J. Burke, and Patrick L. Leone resulted in a complaint and raised questions about police conduct and use of force. As a member of the public, I have a right to access these records to gain a better understanding of the incident and to hold law enforcement accountable.

Please be advised that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint. The failure to comply with FOIL is a serious matter and can result in both criminal and civil penalties. Therefore, I strongly urge you to comply with this request in a timely and complete manner.

Last, I would like to bring to your attention the case law supporting my request:

New York City Administrative Code Section 14-151 (a) requires the New York Police Department to maintain records of all complaints and allegations of police misconduct, including records of investigations and findings.

New York State Committee on Open Government, Advisory Opinion #2016-4 (2016) states that police body-worn camera footage is presumptively available under FOIL.

Matter of Fappiano v. New York City Police Department, 95 A.D.3d 981 (2d Dep't 2012) held that "FOIL represents a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed."

New York Times Co. v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 756 F.3d 100, 117 (2d Cir. 2014) (holding that "the public has a vital interest in information regarding the operations of its government" and that the FOIA "embodies the basic principle that an informed citizenry is essential to democracy").

Matter of DaimlerChrysler Corp. v. Spitzer, 7 N.Y.3d 653, 663 (2006) (stating that "FOIL, like FOIA, reflects a strong policy in favor of open government, and its exemptions must be narrowly construed").

Please note that any attempt to withhold, redact, or destroy information related to this request will result in legal action and complaint.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Good Citizen
